reviewText:
Fun little sandbox to play in.  It has a bit of a mobile feel to it, but seems to work very well with no notable bugs.  Didn't notice any graphical issues, and the display scales well just by dragging the window to be larger.

Amusing humor in the tutorial writing/explanations of new scares earned as you go.  From what I have played so far, it feels easy to make mistakes and get way too ahead of yourself/overwhelmed, but that's what learning is for.

Only real complaint is a lack of tooltips explaining exactly what effect different awareness" props have."

reviewText:
I'll start with the bad first even though I do enjoy this game, in the hopes that if there's ever a sequel these can be adressed.

1. Ui, the ui in this game is very archiac and hard to understand at first. In particular manipulating objects. So far I haven't figured out how to rotate or move objects if I even can, all I seem to be able to do is clone and delete objects. It took me a while to figure out how rooms were formed as floors were only an option with no walls like the sims and the first three floor options don't actually make rooms. This also factored into the traps a bit as it seemed like the effective range of traps was only revealed to me after I placed them on the map not previewed before, but I could just be being unattentive.

2. The tutorial for me seems to be bugged as I can't control the ghost at all during it forcing me to skip it which if that hadn't happened I think my first pointwouldn't be as big a deal as it was to me.

3.The isometric view means you can't see everything in your rooms effectively, and also you can't place objects right up against the wall closes to you as the spot seems to be obscured, both visually and mechanically you can't interact with it once a wall covers it.
I don't mind the isometric view I just wish I could place items right up to the closest wall so I could have my rooms be symmetrical in some spots.

Finally the resolution options in this game are limited and as I use a normal tv not a Computer monitor with my desktop I couldn't fix the game to work in fullscreen mode making me have to play it in a stretched window mode. It's only a minor complaint but something I felt like noting.

Now with those points out of the way here are the things I liked about the game and why I think it's ultimately still worth playing if it interests you.

I like the aesthetic of the game, especially the ghost himself he's got a cute charm to me the way he giggles and displays different facial expressions throughout gameplay.
There's a surprising variety in the way different humans interact with the house and they're introduced gradually which means you don't get too overwhelemed by them.

The game progresses in sort of mini levels where you have to achieve a size and trap number milestone, to unlock the next set of objects to use in customising as well as more humans with more complex effects on the game.
Your ghost also gains a new scaring ability with each stage progressed into and you can use these at the cost of your resource points to instantly scare any humans in an area of effect around you.

The more scares you pull off in frequent succession the more awareness of your hauntings go's up. With higher awareness more people come to the house both normal people you can scare for points and others like Excorcists Journalists, skeptic bloggers and more that can drain your resources or raise your awareness even more.
So you have to manage having enough awareness to make your haunted house popular, but not too notorious or else the Police investigate the house draining your resources rapidly and leading to an almost guarenteed game over.

The game is surprisingly challenging, if you aren't paying attention you may spend too many resources and find yourself with not enough to keep going as your health and currency are both pulling from the same source. And if you get too carried away with scaring people you might cause one to die of fright sending your awareness meter so high your home will be swarming with cops ending your game very swiftly.

I wasn't expecting this game to be one that required my full attention but it was scanning the map constantly to find certain npcs  Iwanted to scare away before they got to my house or to spook a coward for bonus points kept me constantly looking around the map not just idling on my house and overall I felt it was pretty engaging so far. Gonna play more into it and see how much it draws me in.

Sorry for the rambling but I really wanted to get my full thoughts out on this game. It's rough around the edges, especially with Ui and Resolution options, but it's a great foundation and first attempt in my opinion. A sequel maybe that expanded on the tech side of things while addind more content would be fantastic in my eyes.
As for this one it's a pretty nice game, I enjoy it.

Damn I wrote a lot about this game...

*edit* I forgot thist part, If this game is in a genre that's not already your cup of tea, I do not reccomend it except that it is exceptionally cheap. It's a game at the price of a tin of pringles. I wanted to point out that I only recommend this game if you are already interested by its core mechanics. Otherwise the poor Ui and lack of direction may only be frustrating to you.

reviewText:
This key was obtained from the publisher, TFYC

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EpHSezW-Y8I

Summary:
Look, when it comes down to it, this game has a chance if it can implement some technical fixes, as the core idea of the game does work. The art style may not work for some, but I liked the unique look, and the idea of scaring people worked at the beginning, in terms of using tactics against specific people. Unfortunately, the game has problems over the long haul with variety, and a lack of things like camera rotation, which in a game where you build your house seems to be a critical missing feature, and bugs that plague the game on more then just a crashing level didn't help. The potential for mods helps it, and the fact that a majority of the money goes to charity also helps it, but in it's current state, it just doesn't pass the “fun” test over the long haul.

Lists:

+:
Base idea and gameplay works at the start especially with strategically defending your home.
Cheap price and most of the money goes to charity.
Potential for mod support helps the game immensely in the long run.
Like the art style, it does feel unique and the character designs stand out when looking at them on an individual basis.
-:
Missing features like camera rotation are very problematic, especially for elements of building, and the inability to really “customize” your home doesn't help either.
At this time, too many crashes and bugs to count, as well as performance issues when recording (FRAPS specifically). I'm not even sure the video as I showed didn't have a bug with the 999999 thing.
Gameplay gets stale after a while due to a lack of variety. You'll be doing a lot of the same thing.
Has waterfall problems, specifically, when things start going down the drain, you won't be able to recover reasonably.
UI feels unfinished or just plopped on at times. Elements that should be highlighted when effected blended into the background.
Game is exploitable in terms of tactics, at least in my opinion.

reviewText:
I have played about 3 hours on the beta for Afterlife Empire, and just over an hour on the steam release now. I really want to say that this is a solid game. While it does have it's flaws, it offers fun gameplay and hours of enjoyment at a very reasonable price.

Pros: A solid sim/strat game that offers good replayability. The audio is decent but not amazing. The graphics are the same. The graphics feel more like they were made for a tablet/mobile phone game than a straight out PC release. But the game runs very smoothly. The only bugs I encountered were during the tutorial. The gameplay is more casual than most of the Theme games, or Sim games, but that actually helps to work in it's favor imo. I could play for 20-30 minutes and feel I accomplished something, or I could play for an hour or more. This is a game that I will recommend to my friends who like sim/strat type games or who like mobile/casual games. For the price it is a serious buy.

Cons: The few bugs I did see were during the tutorial. I could not click on objectives, and had to escape out of the tutorial during the beta (so these bugs MAY be fixed now). This made it harder to get into the game at first. The graphics, for a PC game, could be better. For my taste I would enjoy more RPG elements, i.e. levelups, or stats... but that is my own personal taste.

Warning!: There is some controversy surrounding this game because of the #GamerGate situation. I say forget that crap and give the game a try yourself. For the $5 pricetag you get a lot more out of it then most games that are 15-20 bucks on release. I have enjoyed my time playing this game and I hope you will as well.

reviewText: Bugs, glitches and a rather unintuitive UI (no tooltips, or ways to check current objectives) mar this game. It's very clear that this game could've done with a few more weeks of polishing. However, the basic concept is pretty fun. It's very similar to Ghost Master, where you scare the inhabitants and or visitors of your home, except that game is a tad more indepth. Considering this is a first attempt from The Fine Young Capitalists, don't expect any panty droppers... just a simple, fun game where you scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of unsuspecting people looking for a thrill. I think my favorite part of the game is the varied number of characters, their reactions and the character models themselves. A very interesting artstyle to say the least. All in all, it's worth 5 bucks and it makes for a passable first outing. Can't wait to see what else comes from this company.\nImpressions:\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AoTheNlPOjA

reviewText: I enjoy Afterlife Empire. It's a cute management-style game with the unique idea of managing your own haunted house. It took me around half an hour to fully understand the controls, status bars, and how to properly keep my house running, but once I understood it all it was a blast! There are a few minor bugs that still need to be ironed out, but for $5, I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a neat little game to pass the time with. The profits go to charity too!
voteText: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclosure: I supported The Fine Young Capitalists Indiegogo Campaign.

Well to start you're dead. And that's ok. Now it's time to haunt your house before you fade away!

To get to the nitty and gritty the core of this game is to expand your haunted house while dealing with a variety of threats looking to exorcise your ghostly self. The core resource is energy which is replenished by scaring people. But be careful as building your house costs energy too! Also scaring people can raise awareness which results in your house getting demo'd. You have to strike a careful balance between gathering energy to stay in the game and expand while managing your awareness against a variety of people wandering around your ghostly home. Reporters, cops, exorcists, and more will have to be carefully dealt with so they don't interrupt your bread and butter walking energy nuggets.

The artwork is cute and the gameplay engaging. I don't generally care overly much when it comes to these sorts of games however I find it to be quite enjoyable. It's also about $4.50 which is crazy cheap. For the bad however I do find the interface and controls to be counter-intuitive at times. Zooming in and out feels inverted and you can't for example open the options menu via escape but you have to use escape to close it. It's doesn't really hinder the gameplay any but it does take some getting used to.

Ultimately I'd say if this kind of game is up your alley and you have $5 go ahead and give it a go. I highly doubt you'll regret it.
voteText: 20 of 29 people (69%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Afterlife Empire's an unusual beast. A very simple little game, it simultaneously calls to mind games like Roller Coaster Tycoon and Theme Hospital - only in this case, you're one little ghost who's trying to continue to exist. The game drops you right in with a fairly straightforward tutorial, explaining various bits of the game relatively quickly and in succession. The goal is to build up your Haunt by scaring the natives and improving your ghost house.

But you have to be careful - because your scare energy is also your currency used to scare people directly, you can't spook all your ghost shekels in one place - better to save those skeleton dollars in the ghost bank, an-- stupid jokes aside, it's an unusual game in that you have to manage the scare energy you get carefully, resisting the temptation to splurge on one big item for your home without a little bit of scare energy in the bank just in case!

The game's humor is very tongue-in-cheek and both colorful and interesting to watch.

Pros:
* Simple, accessible fun
* Humorous as all hell with clever ideas
* Surprisingly bright and well-animated
* Character designs are cute and well-done
* Excellent asking price
* Mod-friendly
* More updates coming!

Cons:
* Music is pretty mediocre
* Screams can get somewhat repetitive
* Game feels somewhat like an ascended mobile game
* Audio can glitch if too much happens at once
* Progression is a little awkward
* Some parts of the game need to be tutorialized better

reviewText:
Game crashed on me after three rounds.

There are typographical errors, no mouseover effects on menu items, camera moves too quickly in windowed mode, no autosave that I can tell after you successfully complete a night, and unclear tooltips in the prop menu.

This game needed more time to bake in the oven.  It's a half-completed mess, especially in the visual department.  Although the character models are charming, they don't mesh properly with the environment designs.  The font is rendered jaggedly in windowed mode.

Something that personally irritated me in regards to the tree tileset is that they weren't transparent if something was behind them, making it kind of difficult to see if there was someone to scare.  Not sure if that was intentional or not, but I find it misguided.

NOTE: If there are updates pending, I'll come back and check out the progress and revise this review as needed.

reviewText:
This game sort of reminds me of xbill if you've ever played it on Linux based systems.  Where in xbill you are protecting your network from little Bill clones, in this game you are protecting your haunted house from Exorcists and Home Renovation Enthusiasts.  The main difference is that you are also building the house as you play (unlike the prebuilt network in xBill), and the traps in the house generate energy.  So, it's split between two modes.  Build mode (action is paused) where you add rooms, traps, decor (necessary to keep the bulldozers from coming) and ghost mode, where you frantically try to scare away threats.

Exorcists kill you, given enough time, Renovators kill your traps (preventing the house from generating the energy you need to survive).  As the game progresses, the house gets bigger and bigger and you get a second attack (smaller area but uses less energy).

I expect once you get used to the controls, you will probably put a lot of time into this game.  Not so much as sitting for a whole day playing it, but pulling it up when you have an hour to kill here and there. Now, I have only had a few hours to play it, but that's enough to recommend it to people looking for a game in this category. (I will say there are both more options for traps, and new threats as the game progressed, so I haven't seen everything it has to offer yet.)

reviewText:
Seeing Vivian in the opening credits really made me grin, so keep in mind this review is biased.

That in mind, the game is only five dollars and I've already gotten a few hours of entertainment out of it. The basic idea is simple and fun, similar to rollercoaster tycoon as others have pointed out, but with a supernatural twist.

There are a number of glitches. The tutorial often freezes and you have to esc out of it to continue playing. When you load saved levels walls will sometimes be missing. Nothing bad enough to make me ragequit, but I can see someone who'd worked longer on their house getting pretty upset over it.

reviewText:
While I do find this game to be worth the five bucks, and recommend it, it does have it's fair share of problems.  I didn't expect TOO much for only five dollars, and I'm ultimately satisfied with what I got.


THE GOOD:
* The gameplay is fun enough.  You can design the rooms to have certain themes and have a variety of traps to scare people (to death) with.  You also get several different scare powers" that are better used in different conditions.

* It gets pretty challenging as you progress.  With more people showing up
date:
there are also those who will deplete your resources and disable/steal your traps.  You have to watch out for them.  It makes you keep your focus while playing.

* I like the visual style of the game.  They took their time designing the different characters in the game along with various animations.

* The game has some decent humor.  You can click the characters to have them say something (The exorcist will want to "cleanse this place in the name of fettuccine").  There's other funny little things scattered throughout the game.


THE BAD:
* The tutorial was broken (and from looking at other reviews
recommended: it wasn't just me).  I had trouble moving the ghost to the two teenagers

reviewText:
This game was incredibly confusing to me in the beginning, mainly because the tutorial glitched out. I was left on my own to figure out how to spend points, make my house, and scare people.

After 3 tries I finally got the tutorial to work to the point where it told me how to build rooms, this was incredibly helpful and I advanced to round 3 in that run. Then the game froze; music still worked but everything was frozen. I shut it down and restarted my save from just after round 1.  Now everytime I load that file it freezes in less than a minute.

In order to play the game more I will have to start a new game, trudge through all the tutorial text again (or miss any helpful bonus (like a new room) that I recieved in it, and pray that it doesn't freeze like the last one. At this point, I am just trying to complete the achievements but I don't even know if that's possible anymore.

Overall?:
+Great game. It's a unique concept and the visuals are cute as well. It has the potential to be interesting and fun.

-The controls are horrible. Everytime I have to click on the shop my camera moves and I had to figure out how to move in in the pause screen. Let me explain, when you are in ghost mode
date:
which is when you scare people and watch people get scared by your traps, you move the camera (which does not rotate) by dragging your mouse to the edge of the screen. When you are in shop/edit mode, which is when you click on the shop to buy/place anything, you have to hold down the right mouse button and drag the screen. Because this was so different from ghost mode" it took me quite a while to figure out.

-Crashes and corrupted save files. I already explained this but I can no longer access my save.

-Reptetive. Every unique character
hoursPlayed: has the same look and sayings as the multiple copies running around. It gets a bit tiring after a while. I can't say that there isn't more variety in late game, as I am unable to get there, but I would like to see more variety in the little snippets of text if nothing else.\n\nUntil the bugs are fixed I cannot reccomend this game.

reviewText:
Heyyo, well for what I paid for? $5 is an ok asking price for the game. There's not a lot to this game, it doesn't have a lot of depth but it's a decent first game by a studio that has never made games before.

I do wish there was more to the game as it definitely feels short as all  you do is either directly scare people, build rooms to scare people... that's about it.

There's a few special types of humans you need to watch out for as they can take you down or cause a game over. You have essense that you need to keep you alive but it's also the same power you use to scare humans or build the rooms.

I dunno, there's just not a lot to talk about... but like I said, it set out some basic goals and achieved them with a team of ladies that have never made games before so it's alright for a first game. If you're looking for a more in depth indie game? Of course on Steam there's a lot to try.

reviewText:
------------------------------------------
revisited after some patching
------------------------------------------

the bad:
------------
-tutorial didnt work. ESC fixed that by skipping it, but this time the first 2 steps worked

-crashes when the house gets big (~18-20k)

-non-existant options menu (ESC doesnt bring it up)
>only music + sound slider, turning off tips + enemy-marker
>no keybinding menu
>no checkboxes to reverse stuff
>no graphics menu (questionable if thats needed)

-basic controls - no changes possible
>right mousebutton, X+Y axis are reversed.
>scrolling via mouse to the sides of the screen is incredibly slow (also the scrolling starts when the cursor is half way on the building/ghostmode-icons)
>mousewheel zoom in&out seems to be reversed (in comparison to similar games) (also it doesnt zoom out enough when the house gets really big (~30min-1h in))
(-space (to focus on the ghost) is pointless since u´ll be moving when things get busy)

-erase stuff:
>doors - bit fiddly
>deco - very fiddly
>traps - not possible. works by putting 1 spot of gras under the trap so it´s wall´ed out, so u can drop a better trap
>rooms/walls - none. only by covering areas with gras

-epilepsy&seizures warning at the end of the credits, which u scroll up&down via mouse Y-axis and it goes so fast i´m getting both when i read about them. i guess that´s on purpose :p


the good:
---------------
+nice animations

+overall look is decent

+setting is fun

+only ~5€

+charity

+vivan james



needs fixing:
-------------------
>removing stuff
>crashes
>tutorial
>disappearing special enemy markers


whats missing:
----------------------
>options menu (!!)
>add autosave after x-minutes
>hardmode (no pause when building stuff)


non-game issue:
-------------------------
https://twitter.com/TFYCapitalists/status/631483181632475136
~3-5% of money goes to femfreq. since this was a backers-voting decision it is legit but something to keep in mind if u have moral concerns when it comes to giving con-artists any money. maybe somewhat of a dealbreaker, since they haven´t made anything productive in my opinion.
on the plus-side real charitys get some money and the frauds will get money somehow.


how it plays&works:
---------------------------------------
>controls very IOS-ish (plays like a bad port) (options menu can fix it)
>lvl up, gather a ton of energy/currency, delete everything via gras, rebuild since u´ve probably f*cked up somewhere, make it pretty, hope it doesnt crash in the process
>nice mix of building + keeping the special enemys at bay via different cooldowns


conclusion:
-----------------
>get stuff fixed fast. atm this is a beta-version at best
>do i keep it?
yes b/c charity (seriously look it up, u might disagree a big one).
>hoping for a second part with a less casual approach for the gameplay and a fleshed out building system

reviewText:
Ein kurzer Gameplay Ausschnitt ist hier zu sehen

https://youtu.be/2hzOh2aJ180


Was ist Afterlife Empire?
Es handelt sich um ein Theme PArk/HOspital-artiges Spiel in einer Art Spuk-Setting. Man spielt einen Geist, der sein Dasein damit verbringt, Leute in in Spukhaus zu locken und zu erschrecken. Dadurch erhält man Spuk-Energie, die man benötigt, um verschiedene Fähigkeiten des Geistes zu benutzen und um alle Möglichen Objekte zu kaufen und das Spukhaus auszubauen. Sollte die Energie auf 0 fallen, ist das Spiel verloren.

Level oder Missionen werden in dem SPiel so gehandhabt, dass man im Grunde immer eine gewisse Anzahl an Räumen und Fallen" bauen muss
date: um "aufzusteigen". Hierdurch erhält man neue Fähigkeiten und Objekte und es kommen immer mehr verschiedene Menschen in das Haus

The best thing I can say about this game is that the price is appropriate.

There's nothing particularly wrong with the game, it's just uninspired. It's mildly entertaining in a simple sort of way. If it were a mobile game, I might play it on the bus.

The graphis are meh, the music is meh, the sound effects are meh, the gameplay is meh. It's all just meh.

Not bad. Just not good either.

reviewText:
Not gonna lie, it needs work. Feels like an alpha to be honest. I love games like theme hospital but the biggest draw of those games is building your game area and squeezing out every bit of money you can from every square available, here you can't really do much. Each room can only have one scare item in it so can't really maximize efficiency in a large room. As soon as anyone walks into a trap they immediately run clear out of the house, so there's no real point to make more rooms except to fill them with props to distract cops. You can't rotate anything which makes it annoying for someone with OCD that loves decorating in these types of games. It crashes a lot, often times for no reason it'll just stop responding can't click anything or do anything. Huge issue though is you can't delete traps, you rebuild a room with different tiles it'll get rid of props but not traps, once you place one it's there for ever which is especially annoying when you get better traps because people will walk into the first trap and run out of the house completely ignoring all others

I'd suggest drop down walls, that way you don't need to have a full camera rotation but can still see well in the mansion. Rotatable items is a must, really helps decorating a house. Traps that work in different ways, doors that lock behind a character so they can't run out and have to run your terror maze, traps or scares that will chase someone in a specific direction to set off a combo scare or something.

I won this game so didn't cost me, but I wouldn't have felt ripped off if I had. I would've kept it cause it can be fun and I do see potential if they keep working on it. But as of right now? It's hard to recommend.

Tl;Dr: A fun game despite some noticeable issues, needs some work but for 5 dollars I'd say it's a fine price for what it is and would recommend it if you're a fan of the old theme style games.

reviewText:
As it is I cannot recommend this game, the tutorial seems broken right off the bat, had to restart the game six times and switch to fullscreen to finally get the ghost too move to the end of the path when i clicked, (Think it may be due to resizing the window, last time i did the game just stopped responding)
If it gets fixed I'd give this another chance since it seems like an interesting concept and would probably be a great deal for the price, but I  can't justify buying it when something as early as the tutorial seems a mess.
Also some way to change the zoom in and out would be nice, used to the scroll wheel working the other way round.
The UI wasn't terribly impressive either the transparent background might be useful in gameplay i guess, but it looks really off.

reviewText: I had a lot of problems with this game unfortunately and really wanted to like it.  It's cute, and I was expecting a theme hospital style game.  Unfortunately the tutorial is bugged and the UI hung on me... esc (which exits the tutorial) fixed the issue, but of course then I don't have the tutorial.  The options menu was much less than I expected, would be nice to actually have some video options.  Tooltips explaining what items do, and explaining the mechanics of the game a bit more would have been nice too.  I'd also like to see some actual tasks put into the game, not just some sort of endless survival... though I didn't play much of the game so maybe that comes later.  Ultimately the game crashed on me, and coupled with the issues I had I can't recommend the game and even requested a refund.  Hopefully they can fix the issues and I might pick it up again.

reviewText:
Originally on: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Vivian-James-v/1490762111170956

Afterlife Empire Review (2) Reviews
Disclosure:
(Both admins received the game for free)
(I couldn't play it on my pc since it's broken, so I visited my friend to play it on his pc)
My time playing (3 hours)
I honestly can't really recommend this game...unless it gets a major update. I played the beta on pc and I couldn't get the damn tutorial to work and I still can't get it to work...I thought they would get that fixed by now. The options menu isn't really an option menu, there's practically nothing there. The controls are just odd...when I try to move the screen to see the NPCs, it just flips on me and goes to the wrong direction on it's own.
There's a lack of direction in the game, there's really nothing that makes me want to play it. Your only objective is to scare the ♥♥♥♥ of people, but I feel like you could just use the vase all day to scare people with and the ghost when you have to.
It's just not a finished product, I know the game developers behind AE are amateurs, but if you need more time to fix the game, then reschedule the release date. People will be more understanding if you need more time to fix the game.
The game crashed on me 3 times and my friend's computer is pretty beefy (Will edit in the specs in the review later)
Yeah the review isn't really that lengthy or that full in depth. I just can't wright much about it since I don't fully understand the game because I couldn't get the tutorial to work.
Rate: 3/10
Other main admin's review
Playtime (1 hour)
It's garbage.
Better than depression quest I guess.

reviewText:
Cute game.  I'm a big fan of Haunting (Genesis) and Ghost Master and I was hoping it would be similar.
Game is fun for wasting a few minutes. It would work a lot better on a mobile platform.

I like the visual style and the NPC responses are pretty funny.  The music gets pretty annoying and I usually turn it off.

User Interface and User Experience needs some work, tooltips would help, or at least a better tutorial.

Just an example of how the UX could be improved, there were a few times I thought my game locked up, when in fact, it was only because I selected a different section than the ghost.   Some indicator that the game is paused would help.

I played this on a Mac and there were a few lock-ups (or at least I think they were..again, hard to tell with the UI/UX).

Even so, I'm having fun with the game, but there's undoubtably a large room for improvement.
Be wared, I've heard this game has its share of game-breaking bugs, but I haven't experienced any, so hopefully they've sorted all that out.

reviewText: Although I enjoy the concept of the game, I believe the style may be more suited for mobile gaming as its simplicity and addictiveness seems like it would be more enjoyed on the busride to school/work or when a computer is not accessible. It's not very complex so I have a hard time finding myself getting lost in the gameplay for any more than half an hour. Playing in short spurts seems to be the most enjoyment I get out of the game.\n\nI have read before time and again the bugs are still acting up in the game (as I had bought this for my friend and alas, he still cannot get past the loadscreen) and although I have not experieneced any of these problems, it would be reasonable to expect the game to be fixed by now. I hope to hear more from the developers soon, but at this time I cannot recommend this game in good faith. If it hits mobile markets though, you'll be sure to see me there!

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I'm really rather sad that this game never got to go further.
Unfortunately, it still feels very alpha. It's a cute game, I like it, and I enjoyed playing it. However, it's no longer a game I have much interest in.
I absolutely do recommend it, but expect the game to crash, for there to be silly glitches, and to eventually stop playing it all together.

It feels like the biggest issue here was the fact that they got a lot of hate for something as stupid as where money went based on a public voting system. It seemed to discourage the devs, who, quite frankly, were doing a damned good job. If people judged the game and only the game, this would have gone a lot further.

So, for $5, you get a few hours of fun gameplay, maybe some more if you get really into it. You'll probably be like me and wish that the devs and publishers had the will to do more.
Maybe one day they'll pick this back up for an update or two, if only to humor people like me.
